title: Do presidents sleep in the same room as past presidents? - Quora
tags: Presidents of the United States of America
History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: While there is no requirement that the president actually use the room himself, there is a Master Bedroom suite on the second floor of the White House Residence, in the southwest corner of the building. The suite consists of the bedroom (picture taken during Obama’s term):  (Picture taken during Clinton’s term, showing the other end of the bedroom):  A Dressing Room (usually used as a private study for the First Lady in recent times):  And the Master Bath (picture taken during Truman’s term, so probably terribly outdated now):

The Lincoln bedroom is so called because the bed in that room is his. The actual bedroom was demolished during the Truman administration, when the White House was gutted and the interior completely rebuilt. So no president has slept in a White House room occupied by any predecessor before Truman. The White House has living quarters for the First Family. I should think the Secret Service would veto any decision by a president to set up a cot, a mini-fridge and a wide-screen TV in the East Room or the Oval Office and declare that he wanted to use that room as his bedroom.

Same toilet seat too. Altho they usually don’t fall asleep there. Most presidents won’t admit it, but they still see Lincoln’s ghost in their bedroom. They don’t want to admit it or you’d think they were losing it. Still, Winston Churchill once visited the White House and saw Lincoln’s ghost, top hat and all. After that night, he refused to ever sleep there again. Queen of the Netherlands had the same experience.

Edited because I didn’t know the history of the “Lincoln Bedroom”… I would say of course. They can’t just go and add on a new bedroom every time a new POTUS is elected, so obviously they’ve used the same bedrooms over the years.
